node.title: Its Human Rights Record in Question, China Turns to an Old Friend
node.description: The International Olympic Committeeâ€™s professed neutrality has provided coverage for Beijing, which delivers big audiences and funding in exchange.
node.content: ["When China\u2019s leaders came under pressure to answer questions about the health and whereabouts of Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star, they turned to a friendly face.", "They put Ms. Peng on a video call with members of the International Olympic Committee, a global sports organization that for years has turned a blind eye to Beijing\u2019s human rights record. True to their reputation, I.O.C. officials did not ask her about her claim that she had been sexually assaulted by a powerful former Communist Party leader, an allegation that led censors to scrub the details from the Chinese internet.", "Perhaps no international organization has a more symbiotic relationship with Beijing. The Chinese government treats its growing success in sports as symbolic of the country\u2019s rise as a global power. The 2008 Beijing Olympics helped transform the world\u2019s image of China, a feat the government hopes to replicate next month when the Winter Olympics begin near the same city.", "In return, Beijing provided the I.O.C. with access to 1.4 billion potential sports fans and heaps of money. In 2014, the state broadcaster China Central Television signed a broadcasting deal with the I.O.C. that SportBusiness, a news and data service, estimated to be worth about $550 million. China also brought corporate access, like a sponsorship deal with Alibaba, the e-commerce giant, that Bloomberg reported was worth $800 million.", "China\u2019s relationship with the Olympics could be best illustrated by Juan Antonio Samaranch of Spain, who led the I.O.C. for two decades, and the foundation in China that bears his name.", "The Samaranch Foundation was founded by his son, Juan Antonio Samaranch Jr., who is also chair of I.O.C.\u2019s coordination committee for the Beijing 2022 Games, and counts the I.O.C. as a founding partner. The foundation, which has all three Chinese I.O.C. members on its board, is devoted to carrying on the elder Mr. Samaranch\u2019s legacy of courting China, which had made him something of a hero there.", "It has also carried on his legacy of smoothing over China\u2019s troubling conduct. In September 2018, when word was drifting out that as many as one million members of largely Muslim minority groups were detained in internment camps and prisons in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, the foundation organized a charity soccer event there. It has also held events in Tibet, despite longstanding religious suppression there.", "\u201cThe I.O.C. keeps saying that it\u2019s a politically neutral organization, and wants to stay out of politics,\u201d said Yaqiu Wang, a senior researcher at Human Rights Watch in New York. \u201cBut it entirely ignores the fact that it has always been used as a political tool by the Chinese government to legitimize its standing and its policies, including crimes against humanity in Xinjiang.\u201d", "In written comments, the I.O.C. said the Samaranch Foundation operates independently from the committee. The Samaranch Foundation didn\u2019t respond to requests for comments.", "The I.O.C. has also defended its talks with Ms. Peng, a former Olympian, and called criticism \u201csilly.\u201d Thomas Bach, the I.O.C. president, has talked about the importance of \u201cpolitical neutrality\u201d for his organization. \u201cWe can accomplish our mission to unite the world only if the Olympic Games stand above and beyond any and all political differences,\u201d he said in a speech.", "Jules Boykoff, professor of political science at Pacific University in Oregon, said the I.O.C.\u2019s stance only emboldens Chinese leaders.", "\u201cThe I.O.C. typically hides behind the thin scrim of political neutrality,\u201d said Mr. Boykoff, author of \u201cPower Games: A Political History of the Olympics.\u201d \u201cIn the case of Peng Shuai, Bach actively ran political interference for Chinese political authorities.\u201d", "He added, \u201cBach\u2019s willful gullibility in this instance is an important pivot point.\u201d", "After the I.O.C. released a statement saying that Ms. Peng was \u201csafe and well,\u201d several Twitter users commented in Chinese that Mr. Bach reminded them of the elder Samaranch, \u201cthe old friend of China.\u201d That was my reaction, too.", "The I.O.C. has been standing on a moral slippery slope regarding China since the days when Mr. Samaranch Sr. was the president from 1980 to 2001. The country credited him with helping Beijing win its bid to host the 2008 Games. His image and voice were so ubiquitous on Chinese TV that he was known as \u201cGrandpa Samaranch\u201d for children growing up in the 1990s and 2000s.", "He defended China despite wide-ranging criticism of its poor human rights records and suppression of free speech.", "\u201cThe Chinese are people who have long memories and know how to demonstrate their deep feelings of loyalty to people who, in difficult times, have stayed at their side,\u201d Mr. Samaranch wrote in an opinion essay after the Beijing Olympics in 2008. Headlined, \u201cWhy I love and respect China as much as I do,\u201d it was published in a Spanish newspaper, an English-language newspaper in China and the Chinese edition of his biography.", "After his death in 2010, China\u2019s then president sent condolences to the I.O.C. and his family, a gesture usually reserved for heads of state. He called Mr. Samaranch \u201cthe old friend and good friend of the Chinese people\u201d and said China would never forget him. Chinese state media ran many stories commemorating his friendship with China.", "China built a Samaranch memorial, including a park, that is the size of 32 American football fields in the port city of Tianjin.", "The younger Mr. Samaranch founded the Samaranch Foundation in 2012 \u201cto secure the Samaranch-China legacy.\u201d It received donations from the I.O.C., the Chinese Olympic Committee, both the Chinese and the Spanish governments, 10 Chinese companies and others.", "One of its bigger donors is the sportswear maker Anta, which pledged to continue using cotton from Xinjiang, where forced labor was used amid the government suppression of Uyghurs and other Muslim minority groups. Anta\u2019s chief executive sits on the foundation\u2019s board.", "Mr. Samaranch Jr. is mentioned as one of the potential successors to Mr. Bach in 2025.", "The foundation has made it clear where its loyalties lie.", "It celebrated the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People\u2019s Republic of China in a 2019 post on its website, calling it a \u201clove letter.\u201d Earlier this year, it organized a nationwide red-themed running race for middle school students for the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Communist Party.", "Mr. Samaranch Jr. and the foundation he founded are public and unabashed about their love for China, but he insists that it is better to be \u201cquiet\u201d and \u201cdiscreet\u201d when it comes to China\u2019s human rights abuses and Ms. Peng\u2019s allegation.", "When pressed on holding the Games in China, he echoed the committee\u2019s stance that it must separate sports from politics.", "\u201cWe have to keep that neutrality. It is too precious what we are trying to defend,\u201d he was quoted by The Associated Press as saying last month at an online briefing on the preparations for the Beijing Games. \u201cWe are what we are, and we can do what we can do.\u201d", "Then during another online media briefing this week, he urged for a \u201cneed to be discreet\u201d in Ms. Peng\u2019s situation. \u201cEverybody should be concentrating on the well-being of Peng Shuai and not trying to use this for any other purpose,\u201d he said.", "\u201cDon\u2019t write it off the silent diplomacy,\u201d he added. \u201cIt\u2019s a very powerful tool and we plan to stick to that.\u201d", "His father made the argument a long time ago, calling the China critics \u201calarmists.\u201d If anything, the Chinese government has become a lot more authoritarian after the 2008 Beijing Olympics. But it seems, no matter what, the Chinese government can count the I.O.C. as a friend."]
